rationality right so that can be a good thing if you need stuff for your security team right so
reciprocation this one's kind of interesting did anybody buy a car lately somebody purchased a vehicle when you
were in there with the with the car salesman did he offer to buy you a Coke because they always do that right you're
in their little negotiating room or whatever and he says hey Bob can I get you a soda the reason they do that is
that reciprocation is something that we're wired to do we're all wired to respond back when we get something and
that's just you know it's it's our nature is as sort of humans right we we trade we engage in in bartering and all
that kind of stuff what's interesting about the reciprocation response what chalini found is that it doesn't have to
what you reciprocate with does not have to be proportional with what were given so that's kind of cool um so what you
could do there is is look at you know when you go into a battle and you're really talking about something big you've got an externet environment you
need to secure you've got some new project that's not not coming out the way you want it to to be and security is going to get ran over on this thing come
in with some concessions come in with a couple of things that you're ready to kind of concede and start with that
right and so then your opponent is going to reciprocate and maybe they'll maybe they'll move a little closer your
direction right so that's kind of a useful useful tool commitment and consistency is another one uh that
chalini found uh was a kind of a a uh built-in behavior in most people nobody
wants to be a hypocrite nobody wants to contradict themselves there's also things like attribution bias and perception bias and things like that
that once we arrive at some kind of conclusion it takes a lot of evidence to
turn it the other direction right so with that once you persuade say your CIO
to make some kind of foray into security you know we're going to cut down on
